definition: a metallic vessel usually used for boiling liquids
kettledrum
pothole sense 1b
a steep-sided hollow without surface drainage especially in a deposit of glacial drift

a usually large group of raptors (such as hawks or vultures) circling high in the sky on an updraft of warm air                                      
             
             … more than 500 birds have been seen riding the same spiraling thermal air current, or "kettle," as they are known to hawk-watchers.

to corral or contain (people) in large numbers by surrounding and forcing into an enclosed area                                      
             
             Police officers stood in a line in front of them but protesters seemed to think they'd be allowed through. They were not. Instead, they were kettled with orange nets, and arrested.
a container used for heating or boiling liquid
a pot for boiling liquids
teakettle

definition: to control a crowd of people by surrounding them and preventing them from moving or leaving
a container for boiling water, that has a lid, handle, and spout and is made from plastic or metal
to start to boil water in a kettle
an occasion when police form lines around a crowd of people and prevent them from leaving a particular area

a covered container with a handle and a spout (= opening for pouring), used for boiling water

An irregular air traveler (1-2x/year) who feels entitled to use first class and premium check-in counters, attempts to board during first class or elite boarding groups. Kettles are often oblivious to boundaries such as curtains separating first class from main cabin, or by crowding around Priority boarding lanes to prevent premium customers from accessing them.

An abbreviated response based on the expression, "That's like the pot calling the kettle black." It is a response made when the speaker has just said something that the listner thinks the speaker is just as guilty of as whoever the speaker was criticizing.
The act of being in someone’s face/and or area of space...A variation of the phrase “Getting in someones grill”.
